block.p: Q. Why does fish start smelling awful in the garbage pail so much sooner than meat does?

Q. Why does fish start smelling awful in the garbage pail so much sooner than meat does?

A. Fish contains quite a bit of a substance that gives rise to two chemicals that make the rotten-fish smell, while red meat has hardly any, said Dr. Joseph H. Hotchkiss, a professor of food science at Cornell University.

The two chemicals are trimethylamine and dimethylamine, both derived from trimethylamine oxide, which is particularly common in the flesh of fin fish, especially cold-water, surface-dwelling ocean fish like the cod. Ocean fish start to smell faster than, say, catfish, Dr. Hotchkiss said.

When the fish is killed and exposed to the action of air, its own enzymes and bacteria, Dr. Hotchkiss explained, that causes the trimethylamine oxide to undergo a chemical process called carboxylation. The products are amines, which are volatile and quite odoriferous.

Fish dealers test for the amount of amines to determine how fresh fish is, ''and the consumer's nose knows, too,'' Dr. Hotckiss said. ''But those who do not eat fish find it more objectionable than others.

''When I pass around a vial with the chemicals that cause fish to stink in a beginning food science class, the reactions differ,'' Dr. Hotchkiss said. ''Students from inland northern countries find it obnoxious; those from southern marine areas, with different cultural backgrounds and food habits, find it much less offensive.''
